images.copyright: Roland's Breach, Ordesa y Monte Perdido National Park, Spain (© Inaki Relanzon/Nature Picture Library/Alamy Stock Photo)
images.title: Info
images.caption: Roland's Breach, Spain
images.copyrightonly: © Inaki Relanzon/Nature Picture Library/Alamy Stock Photo
images.desc: High up in the Pyrenees, there is a gap in the mountains. More than 90 metres tall and 39 metres wide, Roland's Breach, featured here today, is a sight to behold. But who was Roland? Count Roland was a Frankish military leader during Charlemagne's reign in the 8th century. Legend has it that, after being defeated in battle, Roland cut a gap in the mountains—either to destroy his sword or to catch one last glimpse of France.

images.copyright: Prioro, Castile and León, Spain (© Ruben Earth/Getty Images)
images.title: Info
images.caption: Prioro, Castile and León, Spain
images.desc: In the heart of Castile and León, Spain, Prioro is a picturesque and charming village, surrounded by majestic mountains and lush forests. It has a serene beauty that makes it the perfect refuge for those seeking an escape from the hustle and bustle of everyday life. The nearby mountains become an ideal setting for outdoor activities such as hiking or skiing, while the crisp mountain air fills the lungs with purity and tranquility.

images.copyright: Short-eared owl hunting in heavy snow (© Dilshan Muthalib/Getty Images)
images.title: Info
images.caption: Short-eared owl
images.desc: The short-eared owl, featured in today's image, is a grassland-dwelling member of the owl family. Found on all continents except Antarctica and Australia, it's one of the most widely distributed bird species. This raptor belongs to the genus Asio, whose members are characterised by feather tufts ('ears') on their head. The short-eared owl only reveals its tufts when feeling defensive.

images.copyright: Zoroaster Temple, Grand Canyon National Park, Arizona, USA (© Nick Lake/Tandem Stills + Motion)
images.title: Info
images.caption: Grand Canyon National Park, Arizona, United States
images.desc: Carved by the Colorado River, nearly 2 billion years of Earth's history are exposed in the layers of the Grand Canyon. While geologists continue to debate parts of the formation story of the canyon, recent studies suggest the river carved its path through the region about 5 to 6 million years ago. Since then, the river has been deepening and widening the canyon while sculpting its dramatic geographic features.

images.copyright: European beech forest in Belgium (© Philippe Moes/Minden Pictures)
images.title: Info
images.caption: European beech forest, Belgium
images.desc: Beech trees are pretty amazing. There are several species worldwide, but the European beech steals the spotlight in much of Europe. With its smooth grey bark, short trunk and sweeping branches, this tree is a standout in Belgium's forests, as shown in today's image. It grows in temperate regions and prefers well-drained, fertile soils, taking up to 30 years to mature. Not only do these 48-metres-tall trees dominate the landscape, but their wood is also used to make some of the sturdiest furniture, flooring and even kitchen tools.

images.title: Info
images.caption: Porto, Portugal
images.desc: Today's image takes us to a city that is bold, unpolished in the best way and brimming with personality. While it's famous for its port wine (cheers to that!), there's so much more to discover in the Portuguese city of Porto. As you walk through its streets, you'll notice façades adorned with azulejos—painted tin-glazed ceramic tilework found in Portugal and Spain—historic churches like São Francisco and the iconic Dom Luís I Bridge, which spans the Douro River, which runs through the city.

og.title: Porto, Portugal

images.copyright: Strokkur geyser in Iceland (© John and Tina Reid/Getty Images)
images.title: Info
images.caption: Strokkur geyser in Iceland
images.desc: Strokkur geyser—featured in the image—warms up winter in a completely different way. It is a fountain geyser known for its frequent and reliable eruptions. Located in the geothermal area beside the Hvítá River in Iceland, this geyser erupts every 6 to 10 minutes, shooting hot water 14 to 20 metres into the air, sometimes erupting up to 40 metres. The geothermal valley is also home to a variety of geothermal wonders, including bubbling mud pools, steaming fumaroles and other geysers.

images.copyright: Deer Valley at dusk, Park City, Utah, USA (© Adventure_Photo/Getty Images)
images.title: Info
images.caption: Deer Valley at dusk, Park City, Utah, United States
images.desc: Park City, Utah, United States is a bustling city primarily in Summit County, with a bit of it spilling over into Wasatch County. It's nestled 51 kilometres southeast of downtown Salt Lake City and about 32 kilometres from Sugar House along Interstate 80. In Park City, you'll find everything from the iconic Park City Mountain Resort and Canyons Village to Deer Valley Resort and Woodward Park City. The Utah Olympic Park is also here, along with the Alf Engen Ski Museum and Eccles Salt Lake 2002 Olympic Winter Games Museum. For culture buffs, there's the Park City Museum and Eccles Centre Theatre, plus Main Street shopping, dining and an outlet mall. And let's not forget the hundreds of kilometres of hiking and biking trails. Whether you're visiting in winter or summer, the four resorts and Olympic Park have activities for everyone.
